Petar, CTRNNs can be really hard to callibrate right to get them 
working a=
t first.  They are very sensitive to things like the range 
of time constan=
ts, range of weights, etc.  If any of those are 
wrong, it can easily tip i=
t away from oscillation-type behaviprs 
into more likely hitting stable sta=
tes.  Unfortunately, I don't 
remember the exact right values for this stuf=
f to get it to work 
well with a regular sigmoid, but it appears that for s=
ome reason 
tanh is less sensitive to specific parameters.  Is it because t=
anh 
is signed and the exponential sigmoid is unsigned?  I'm not sure.  
Bu=
t if you want it to work with the exponential, you can probably 
get it wor=
king by playing around:  make a small network by hand and 
tweak its values=
 by hand while watching animations of what it does 
until you get oscillati=
ons.  You might find that for example changes 
of 0.01 are more effective t=
han changes of 0.1.  Things like that 
take trial and error to figure out.
=

I am sure also that Tyler Streeter would be happy to answer your 
question=
s if you sent him email.

ken
